item.title: Oil industry split on climate law protests
item.description: A rift has broken out within the US oil industry over a controversial plan to deploy thousands of workers in so-called “Energy Citizen” rallies protesting against imminent climate legislation

item.title: Afghan poll imperilled by brazen attack
item.description: Senior election officials in Afghanistan warned that a suicide bomb attack outside the Nato headquarters in Kabul threatened to imperil Thursday’s vote if repeated in the coming days

item.title: UK defends its healthcare
item.description: The fractious British political classes have united in defence of the UK’s healthcare system asafter it has become a byword for the failings of universal, state-funded provision among the US Republican right

item.title: A rally with troubling aspects
item.description: Markets worldwide are pricing in a lot of good news, worrying analysts who believe this rebound will run out of steam

item.title: American who visited Suu Kyi to be freed from Burma
item.description: The American man who swam across a lake to visit Burma’s opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi will be released, according to a statement issued by US Senator Jim Webb

item.title: Beijing sets date for emissions cut
item.description: China’s carbon emissions will start falling by 2050, its top climate change policymaker said, the first time the world’s largest emitter has given such a time-frame

item.title: The US economy is still struggling
item.description: Is the worst over? Some recent figures point that way, but for the moment, the emphasis needs to stay on caution not optimism

item.title: US regulators close Colonial
item.description: In the biggest US banking collapse this year, regulators close the Alabama-based bank with $25bn in assets then broker the sale of its branches and deposits to BB&T

item.title: GM and Chrysler steer different paths to recovery
item.description: The ‘new’ General Motors gallops out of the gate with a slew of announcements and other initiatives, while Chrysler has been relatively silent all but invisible apart from run-of-the-mill sales promotions, writes Bernard Simon

item.title: Hamas shootout with Islamist group
item.description: Hamas, the Palestinian group that rules the Gaza Strip, battled against Islamist radicals in a shootout that killed at least 13 people and wounded dozens more
